          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

Being able to access a target's email or files stored in the cloud without burning your prized 0day has proven to be too much for even the most advanced attackers to pass up. In this talk, we will look at how attackers have evolved and adapted their credential phishing operations over the past 10 years, from changes in delivery mechanisms to changes in persistence and exfiltration and how defenses have evolved during that same time. class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">BlueHat v17 || 10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing | Billy Leonard </h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2017-12-09 00:22:50 UTC">Dec 9, 2017</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">1 like</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">799<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="BlueHat Security Conference" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-MSbluehat-48x48.jpg?cb=1575402763" alt="BlueHat Security Conference" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>BlueHat Security Conference</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">While it&#x27;s not kernel 0days or EMET bypasses, credential phishing has been a go-to in attackers toolboxes for many years, rising to prominence during the run up to the 2016 US Presidential Elections. Being able to access a target&#x27;s email or files stored in the cloud without burning your prized 0day has proven to be too much for even the most advanced attackers to pass up. In this talk, we will look at how attackers have evolved and adapted their credential phishing operations over the past 10 years, from changes in delivery mechanisms to changes in persistence and exfiltration and how defenses have evolved during that same time. </p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more" data-cy="read-more-button"><span>Read more</span></button></div></div><div class="MetadataToolbar_root__x4cNG metadata-toolbar" data-cy="slideshow-toolbar"><div class="MetadataToolbar_wrapper__CdZ7u"><div class="actions Actions_root__00yIC"><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI aria-controls=":R2ca7f6:" popovertarget=":R2ca7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R2ca7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" 10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing

Billy Leonard
Threat Analysis Group
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-2-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide3" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-2" alt="Threat Analysis Group
But first, ….
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="Threat Analysis Group
What we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="Threat Analysis Group
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide6" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-5" alt="Threat Analysis Group
Targeted attacks are all really advanced.

The Middle Ages.

Password Alert.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-19-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-19-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-19-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-19-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide20" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-19" alt="Threat Analysis Group

Two Factor Bypass.

Lot&#x27;s of thanks ...
Threat Analysis Group
Counter Abuse Technologies
Jigsaw
SafeBrowsing
Chrome
MSTIC
Yahoo/Apple/FB Intel Teams
OGs
… and a whole cast of characters that are
Kind of a Big Deal.

Questions?

class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12na7f6:" popovertarget=":R12na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/understanding-ransomware/76853906"><span class="sr-only">Understanding ransomware</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Understanding ransomware</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Understanding ransomware for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/PrathanPhongthiproek">Prathan Phongthiproek</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the WannaCry ransomware attack in May 2017. It began by exploiting a vulnerability in Microsoft SMBv1 protocol using NSA hacking tools leaked online. WannaCry encrypted files on Windows computers in over 150 countries, demanding $300 ransom payments in Bitcoin. Key lessons are the attack demonstrated the risks of not applying software patches and the new era of ransomware using worms to spread rapidly across networks. Proactive prevention measures like backups and secure network segmentation are discussed.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13na7f6:" popovertarget=":R13na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/targeted-attacks-62950126/62950126"><span class="sr-only">Targeted attacks</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Targeted attacks" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Targeted attacks</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Targeted attacks for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/expert4u">Rahul</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a presentation about targeted attacks. It defines a targeted attack as one where threat actors actively pursue and compromise a specific target&#x27;s infrastructure while maintaining anonymity. Targeted attacks are considered such when attackers have a specific target in mind. The main goal is to infiltrate the target&#x27;s network and steal information. These attacks are persistent, with attackers expending significant effort to ensure the attack continues beyond the initial infiltration. Motives include information theft, espionage, and sabotage. Various tools are used in targeted attacks, and targets can be individuals, organizations, or sectors like finance, telecom, or healthcare. Case studies of past targeted attacks are also presented.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R14na7f6:" popovertarget=":R14na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R14na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/inside-attacker-an-overview/80218218"><span class="sr-only">Inside Attacker: An Overview</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Inside Attacker: An Overview" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/insideattacker-anoverview-170927140635-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Inside Attacker: An Overview" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/insideattacker-anoverview-170927140635-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Inside Attacker: An Overview</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Inside Attacker: An Overview for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd4na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd4na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd4na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/DustinCollins1">Dustin Collins</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">An insider attacker is defined as a current or former employee, contractor, or other trusted entity that has access to an organization&#x27;s network, systems, or data and intentionally or unintentionally misuses that access. Insider attacks account for 30-50% of cybersecurity incidents according to various studies. Insider threats can be malicious, negligent, or accidental. They are challenging to detect and prevent because insiders have legitimate access that makes their harmful actions difficult to distinguish from regular job functions. Potential solutions include improving security visibility, using red and blue teams to test defenses, following security standards for development, and monitoring behaviors for anomalies using artificial intelligence. However, overly complex security can also reduce productivity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15na7f6:" Bad: A Look into Its Misuse and Why Knowing It Matters for...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" into Its Misuse and Why Knowing It Matters for...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save [DSC DACH 24] AI 4 Bad: A Look into Its Misuse and Why Knowing It Matters for... for later" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/DataScienceConferenc1">DataScienceConferenc1</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As artificial intelligence continues to advance, its potential to address all kinds of complex problems grows. However, the same technological capabilities that can be used for the greater good are also being exploited. In this talk, we will delve into the topic of AI misuse in criminal activities, exploring real-world examples and learning about the techniques behind these attacks. From deepfake scams and automated hacking to AI-driven fraud and beyond, we will shed light on the darker side of AI innovation and understand why knowing it is important for using AI for good!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JonathanOliver26">JonathanOliver26</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document analyzes a spam campaign from April to June 2012 that distributed malware via the Blackhole Exploit Kit. It found 245 separate spam runs spoofing 17-40 organizations each month. The spam used social engineering to trick users into clicking links that led to compromised websites and exploit pages hosting the Blackhole Exploit Kit. These pages attempted to exploit vulnerabilities in browsers and software to download malware like ZeuS and Cridex. The campaign was highly effective due to its scale and use of redirection, compromised sites and thousands of URLs daily, making it difficult for traditional security methods to keep up.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AmplifyPartners">Andrew Manoske</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The rise of a generation of new hackers has propelled a boom in successful cyberattacks and data breaches over the last decade. This generation of &quot;modern adversaries&quot; has caused billions of dollars in damages in the last few years, and both the pace and danger of their attacks continue to grow. 

This presentation analyzes modern hacker adversaries: who are they, how are they circumventing traditional security systems, and what can the information security industry do to detect and stop these new threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17na7f6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes various computer security topics including:

1. It defines computer security and outlines why security is needed and who is vulnerable. It discusses protecting information while allowing authorized access. 

2. It discusses using Google to gather information about targets through search syntaxes like intitle, inurl, and site. It can reveal employee details and unauthorized information. 

3. It discusses sniffers that monitor network traffic without altering it, and tools like Ettercap. It also covers ARP spoofing to get maximum internet speed. 

4. It briefly discusses steganography which is hiding data in images, and risks of embedding hacking tools, compromised server lists, or attack plans. 

5. It defines</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18na7f6"></div><div class="separator attack</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdana7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdana7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdana7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdana7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdana7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Glok17">Vladyslav Radetsky</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the anatomy of a targeted cyber attack known as ShadyRAT. Over 5+ years, ShadyRAT compromised over 70 victims, maintaining persistence for an average of 9 months to steal data. Attackers used open-source intelligence to profile targets, then sent malicious emails to install remote access tools allowing command and control. Stolen data was encrypted and transferred over months without detection. Lessons are that simple attacks can be highly effective when combined with social engineering and long-term access. Vigilance against such advanced persistent threats requires awareness of social media disclosures and carefully handling potentially malicious files and communications.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ana7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ana7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" company&#x27;s infrastructure by preventing a wide range of potential threats from entering or spreading within a network.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dna7f6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/PhillipMaddux">Phillip Maddux</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Presented on May 9, 2018 at SOURCE Conference Boston 
(https://sourceconference.com/events/bos18/). 

This version contains minor updates from previous presentations. 

This talk will provide a quick overview honeypots, an explanation of the cyber deception space, and the benefits of implementing deception as part of your cyber defense program. In addition, this talk will highlight the HoneyDB project, which enables anyone to get started with operating deception sensors and start collecting threat information. Finally, this presentation will describe how I built scalable honeypot sensor collection, employing a &quot;Frankenstein Cloud Architecture&quot;, for minimal cost.</span></div></div><div class="" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/kurtbaumgartner">Kurt Baumgartner</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses targeted cyber attacks in 2011 and beyond. It describes how attackers have invested in developing tools and techniques to infiltrate systems using exploits, malware, and social engineering. Specific examples from 2011 are provided, including exploits of Adobe Flash and Reader. The document also discusses how attacks may evolve in a post-Windows environment as mobile devices and tablets become more prominent targets. It suggests attackers may increasingly focus on platforms like Android and iOS, and looks at early research into exploiting HTML5 features.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Repeating? for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdina7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdina7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdina7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdina7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ValerieLanzone">Valerie Lanzone</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">2016 was a year in which everything was bigger – bigger breaches,  larger attacks, and bigger repercussions. Whether it was the evolution of DDoS attacks into the record-shattering Mirai botnet that disrupted large portions of the internet or insidious commercial banking Trojans available for sale as ready-made malware kits, the tone of cyberattacks darkened in 2016 while illuminating one key fact: many companies are not applying basic security fundamentals to their IT environments.

Attend this webinar to learn:

The top-level security trends from 2016, and what it could mean for 2017, including the political and intellectual property concerns stemming from large-scale data leaks
Why classic attack vectors continue to be a weapon of choice for those seeking to disrupt operations and steal data
Why a lower attack rate for the average security client may not be good news
What steps your organization can take to protect against these attacks</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ina7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1jna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1jna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/underground-education-21151795/21151795"><span class="sr-only">An Underground education</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="An Underground education" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/undergroundeducation-130514025502-phpapp01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="An Underground education" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/undergroundeducation-130514025502-phpapp01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">An Underground education</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save An Underground education for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdjna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/grugq">grugq</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses counterintelligence processes and threats, as well as how professional thieves and hackers have approached counterintelligence. It notes that professional thieves in the late 19th-early 20th century had loose organizational structures, no controlled territory, and no ability to adapt when law enforcement changed tactics, leading to their decline. Hackers today operate with flat structures and in controlled territories like Russia and China, but English hacker communities in hostile environments have developed stronger counterintelligence through necessity. Overall, the document argues that groups must engage in adaptive denial, learning from failures and adapting security practices, or they will not survive competitive threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Using information gathering techniques from social networks, the attacker was able to profile employees at a target company and conduct a simulated attack. The attacker created fake social media profiles, joined common groups as employees, and followed executives. This allowed polling and phishing attempts at a recruiting event. However, the attack was ultimately an &quot;epic fail&quot; due to an HR executive unwittingly exposing a way to halt the attack by tweeting about lost devices and locations. The summary emphasizes how social networks can be used for information gathering but also how risks can be mitigated through monitoring, policies and training.</span></div></div><div class="" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Using information gathering techniques, the author was able to conduct a simulated attack against a company. They created fake social media profiles and linked accounts together to gain trust. They followed key employees on Twitter and LinkedIn. Fake student profiles were also made to interact with HR events. However, the attack failed unexpectedly. The author was then able to compromise an employee&#x27;s device after they lost their phone and got help at a retail store, highlighting the risks of unsecured devices. The author recommends companies monitor social networks like other systems and provide security training.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mna7f6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?
Script kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploits. Instead, they rely on pre-packaged tools and scripts to carry out attacks.

3. How do script kiddies operate?
Script kiddies typically use automated tools to scan for vulnerable systems and networks. Once they identify a potential target, they use pre-written scripts and tools to exploit any vulnerabilities they find. These attacks can take many forms,Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?
Script kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploits. Instead, they rely on pre-packaged tools and scripts to carry out attacks.

3. How do script kiddies operate?
Script kiddies typically use automated tools to scan for vulnerable systems and networks. Once they identify a potential target, they use pre-written scripts and tools to exploit any vulnerabilities they find. These attacks can take many forms,Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?
Script kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploit</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ona7f6:" popover="auto" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/anhlodge">anhlodge</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Scanned by CamScanner




WRTG 391  
Writing Assignment #3 

Synthesis Essay  
(sometimes called a Literature Review) 

Writing Assignment #3 will be a synthesis essay, a format that is sometimes referred to as 
a literature review.  
Organization:  
 
Your synthesis essay should be organized in the following manner: 

• Introduction: Write one or two paragraphs in which you introduce the reader to your 
topic.  

• Body -- the categories into which you are dividing the literature: Divide your sources 
into a few categories.  A suggestion is that you divide them into three to five 
categories. 

• Conclusion: Summarize what the literature says on your topic. 

Approach: 

This semester, you have critiqued an author’s analysis in the critique essay and have critically 
evaluated several articles in the annotated bibliography.  In this assignment you will synthesize the 
ideas of several authors in a synthesis essay, or literature review. 

For your annotated bibliography, you selected a topic based on your interests and, possibly, your 
major.  You constructed a list of 12 references and summarized and critically analyzed them in 150-
200 words each. 

Through this process, you may have seen patterns in the scholarly literature in the topic on which you 
conducted research.  For example, consider the following examples: 

• You may have researched studies in criminal justice and found that there are varying 
opinions on how to respond to criminal behavior among youth.  

• You may have researched studies in psychology and found that counseling strategies for 
victims of domestic abuse tend to fall into four categories. 

• You may have researched graphic communications and discovered that the integration of 
graphics in business report writing has evolved from the 1970s to the present because of 
advancements in technology.  

• You may have researched articles on gerontology and found studies that answered three 
basic questions on how older adults respond to training for physical performance. 

 In the synthesis essay, you will focus your research efforts in a particular area, perhaps 
as a response to what you found while writing the annotated bibliography.  You will then 
conduct more research and synthesize your findings in this synthesis essay. 



Please note that the annotated bibliography was the beginning, not the end, of your research.  You 
might decide to disregard several of the articles you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography 
because they don’t speak to the specific area on which you have decided to write your synthesis 
essay.  You might select one article that you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography, look up 
the articles cited in that article, and “snowball” your research in that way.  

In other words, this process is a recursive one.  You might find reasons to hone in on and narrow your 
topic even further after you have written the annotated bibliography. 

 How to organize the synthesis essay: 

W.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1pna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1pna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Alerts and Twitter searches. 3) It can help with &quot;getting things done&quot; through project management tools and social bookmarking. 4) Social media enables collaboration through sharing slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AndreanneClarke">Andreanne Clarke</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses four key cybercrime trends observed by IBM&#x27;s Emergency Response Services team in 2015: 1) an increase in &quot;onion-layered&quot; security incidents involving both unsophisticated and advanced attackers; 2) a rise in ransomware attacks that encrypt files and demand ransom; 3) growing threats from insider attacks; and 4) cybersecurity becoming a higher priority issue for management. It provides details on each trend and recommendations for organizations to improve security practices such as patching systems, increasing network visibility, training users, and having proper backup and response plans in place.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1sna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1sna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-28" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1tna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1tna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1tna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-seattle-2019-the-cake-is-a-lie-uncovering-the-secret-world-of-malwarelike-cheats-in-video-games/201112400"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdtna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdtna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdtna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdtna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdtna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Santiago Pontiroli

With more than 2.5 billion gamers from all over the world, it&#x27;s no wonder that at least a fraction of them would bring into action additional tools to gain an unfair advantage over their opponents in the virtual world. This is one of the many reasons behind the existence and rapid growth of a multi-million dollar industry that thrives on selling cheats, hacks and modifications to desperate gamers seeking to gain the upper hand in their next match. Let&#x27;s dissect these tools and understand how modern games and anti-cheating technologies can be easily bypassed, all while we get a glimpse of the dubious market and supporting crews that develop, sell, and maintain the commodities in this illegal economy. It&#x27;s not unusual for cheats to be more expensive than the actual games they are trying to profit from, or for players to buy a single title over and over until they can avoid being banned by the protective measures implemented in the first place. Fortnite? Overwatch? League of Legends? If you&#x27;ve heard about these games but you don&#x27;t know what an aim-bot, a wall-hack, or an ESP means, then you might finally understand why all those competitive matches you played have made you feel like a fish out of water. Join me in this presentation and learn the inside-out of an industry that has remained in the shadows for a very long time. I will be presenting real world cheats used by gamers worldwide that in some cases closely mimic techniques that would rival numerous advanced threat actors in the malware ecosystem. Game over? Maybe not….</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1tna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1tna7f6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses some fundamental problems in technology, including a lack of empathy and diversity in teams, an overvaluation of complexity, and misaligned incentives that prioritize growth and headlines over minimizing real-world harm. It argues that technology companies have not been proactively honest about downsides and have failed to learn from past mistakes. Some recommendations are made, including emphasizing empathy and diversity to better predict harm, shifting risk ownership, adjusting incentives away from complexity and towards harm prevention, and teaching these lessons in computer science education.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1una7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgm5jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rh65jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rh65jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rh65jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/shady-rat-vrad/47366474"><span class="sr-only">ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/shadyratvrad-150424045632-conversion-gate01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/shadyratvrad-150424045632-conversion-gate01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ShadyRAT: Anatomy of targeted attack for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mh65jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mh65jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mh65jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mh65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mh65jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Glok17">Vladyslav Radetsky</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the anatomy of a targeted cyber attack known as ShadyRAT. Over 5+ years, ShadyRAT compromised over 70 victims, maintaining persistence for an average of 9 months to steal data. Attackers used open-source intelligence to profile targets, then sent malicious emails to install remote access tools allowing command and control. Stolen data was encrypted and transferred over months without detection. Lessons are that simple attacks can be highly effective when combined with social engineering and long-term access. Vigilance against such advanced persistent threats requires awareness of social media disclosures and carefully handling potentially malicious files and communications.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rh65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rh65jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhm5jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rhm5jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhm5jnf6"><a class="sr-only">Modern phishing-techniques</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Network security is a set of technologies that protects the usability and integrity of a company&#x27;s infrastructure by preventing a wide range of potential threats from entering or spreading within a network.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rim5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-cy="slideshow-title">Honeypots, Deception, and Frankenstein</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Honeypots, Deception, and Frankenstein for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mj65jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mj65jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mj65jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mj65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mj65jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/PhillipMaddux">Phillip Maddux</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Presented on May 9, 2018 at SOURCE Conference Boston 
(https://sourceconference.com/events/bos18/). 

This version contains minor updates from previous presentations. 

This talk will provide a quick overview honeypots, an explanation of the cyber deception space, and the benefits of implementing deception as part of your cyber defense program. In addition, this talk will highlight the HoneyDB project, which enables anyone to get started with operating deception sensors and start collecting threat information. Finally, this presentation will describe how I built scalable honeypot sensor collection, employing a &quot;Frankenstein Cloud Architecture&quot;, for minimal cost.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rj65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rj65jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses targeted cyber attacks in 2011 and beyond. It describes how attackers have invested in developing tools and techniques to infiltrate systems using exploits, malware, and social engineering. Specific examples from 2011 are provided, including exploits of Adobe Flash and Reader. The document also discusses how attacks may evolve in a post-Windows environment as mobile devices and tablets become more prominent targets. It suggests attackers may increasingly focus on platforms like Android and iOS, and looks at early research into exploiting HTML5 features.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkm5jnf6:" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ValerieLanzone">Valerie Lanzone</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">2016 was a year in which everything was bigger – bigger breaches,  larger attacks, and bigger repercussions. Whether it was the evolution of DDoS attacks into the record-shattering Mirai botnet that disrupted large portions of the internet or insidious commercial banking Trojans available for sale as ready-made malware kits, the tone of cyberattacks darkened in 2016 while illuminating one key fact: many companies are not applying basic security fundamentals to their IT environments.

Attend this webinar to learn:

The top-level security trends from 2016, and what it could mean for 2017, including the political and intellectual property concerns stemming from large-scale data leaks
Why classic attack vectors continue to be a weapon of choice for those seeking to disrupt operations and steal data
Why a lower attack rate for the average security client may not be good news
What steps your organization can take to protect against these attacks</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rl65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/grugq">grugq</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses counterintelligence processes and threats, as well as how professional thieves and hackers have approached counterintelligence. It notes that professional thieves in the late 19th-early 20th century had loose organizational structures, no controlled territory, and no ability to adapt when law enforcement changed tactics, leading to their decline. Hackers today operate with flat structures and in controlled territories like Russia and China, but English hacker communities in hostile environments have developed stronger counterintelligence through necessity. Overall, the document argues that groups must engage in adaptive denial, learning from failures and adapting security practices, or they will not survive competitive threats.</span></div></div><div data-cy="slideshow-title">Phreaknic14</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Phreaknic14 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mmm5jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mmm5jnf6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mmm5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mmm5jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JamesRuffer">James  Ruffer</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Using information gathering techniques from social networks, the attacker was able to profile employees at a target company and conduct a simulated attack. The attacker created fake social media profiles, joined common groups as employees, and followed executives. This allowed polling and phishing attempts at a recruiting event. However, the attack was ultimately an &quot;epic fail&quot; due to an HR executive unwittingly exposing a way to halt the attack by tweeting about lost devices and locations. The summary emphasizes how social networks can be used for information gathering but also how risks can be mitigated through monitoring, policies and training.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmm5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rmm5jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Phreaknic14</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Phreaknic14 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mn65jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mn65jnf6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mn65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mn65jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JamesRuffer">James  Ruffer</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Using information gathering techniques, the author was able to conduct a simulated attack against a company. They created fake social media profiles and linked accounts together to gain trust. They followed key employees on Twitter and LinkedIn. Fake student profiles were also made to interact with HR events. However, the attack failed unexpectedly. The author was then able to compromise an employee&#x27;s device after they lost their phone and got help at a retail store, highlighting the risks of unsecured devices. The author recommends companies monitor social networks like other systems and provide security training.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rn65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn65jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Banking or Financial Trojans are already notorious because they have been around for a while, and they count both consumers and financial institutions among their victims. To help better defend against this class of malware, we share analyses of some recent families of financial Trojans. Nick Bilogorskiy, Cyphort&#x27;s Director of Security Research, looks at the specific characteristics associated with a financial Trojan in terms of distribution channel, armoring behavior, attack payload, actors, etc in this presentation.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnm5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rnm5jnf6"></div><div slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/itmaster9">uzair </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?
Script kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploits. Instead, they rely on pre-packaged tools and scripts to carry out attacks.

3. How do script kiddies operate?
Script kiddies typically use automated tools to scan for vulnerable systems and networks. Once they identify a potential target, they use pre-written scripts and tools to exploit any vulnerabilities they find. These attacks can take many forms,Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?
Script kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploits. Instead, they rely on pre-packaged tools and scripts to carry out attacks.

3. How do script kiddies operate?
Script kiddies typically use automated tools to scan for vulnerable systems and networks. Once they identify a potential target, they use pre-written scripts and tools to exploit any vulnerabilities they find. These attacks can take many forms,Famous script kiddie groups
The evolution of script kiddies
Conclusion
FAQs
1. Introduction
As technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.

2. What are script kiddies?

class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/anhlodge">anhlodge</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Scanned by CamScanner




WRTG 391  
Writing Assignment #3 

Synthesis Essay  
(sometimes called a Literature Review) 

Writing Assignment #3 will be a synthesis essay, a format that is sometimes referred to as 
a literature review.  
Organization:  
 
Your synthesis essay should be organized in the following manner: 

• Introduction: Write one or two paragraphs in which you introduce the reader to your 
topic.  

• Body -- the categories into which you are dividing the literature: Divide your sources 
into a few categories.  A suggestion is that you divide them into three to five 
categories. 

• Conclusion: Summarize what the literature says on your topic. 

Approach: 

This semester, you have critiqued an author’s analysis in the critique essay and have critically 
evaluated several articles in the annotated bibliography.  In this assignment you will synthesize the 
ideas of several authors in a synthesis essay, or literature review. 

For your annotated bibliography, you selected a topic based on your interests and, possibly, your 
major.  You constructed a list of 12 references and summarized and critically analyzed them in 150-
200 words each. 

Through this process, you may have seen patterns in the scholarly literature in the topic on which you 
conducted research.  For example, consider the following examples: 

• You may have researched studies in criminal justice and found that there are varying 
opinions on how to respond to criminal behavior among youth.  

• You may have researched studies in psychology and found that counseling strategies for 
victims of domestic abuse tend to fall into four categories. 

• You may have researched graphic communications and discovered that the integration of 
graphics in business report writing has evolved from the 1970s to the present because of 
advancements in technology.  

• You may have researched articles on gerontology and found studies that answered three 
basic questions on how older adults respond to training for physical performance. 

 In the synthesis essay, you will focus your research efforts in a particular area, perhaps 
as a response to what you found while writing the annotated bibliography.  You will then 
conduct more research and synthesize your findings in this synthesis essay. 



Please note that the annotated bibliography was the beginning, not the end, of your research.  You 
might decide to disregard several of the articles you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography 
because they don’t speak to the specific area on which you have decided to write your synthesis 
essay.  You might select one article that you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography, look up 
the articles cited in that article, and “snowball” your research in that way.  

In other words, this process is a recursive one.  You might find reasons to hone in on and narrow your 
topic even further after you have written the annotated bibliography. 

 How to organize the synthesis essay: 

W.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rom5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rom5jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Darahd">Darah Darrington</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses how social media can be used to strengthen work. It identifies 5 key aspects of social media: 1) Conversations build trust and help communities collaborate. 2) Social media is about listening to what others are saying through tools like Google Alerts and Twitter searches. 3) It can help with &quot;getting things done&quot; through project management tools and social bookmarking. 4) Social media enables collaboration through sharing documents and photos online. 5) When used effectively, social media can help build movements by connecting people to leaders, ideas, and each other.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm5jnf6:" class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Quarterly Q4 2015</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Quarterly Q4 2015 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mq65jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mq65jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mq65jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mq65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mq65jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AndreanneClarke">Andreanne Clarke</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses four key cybercrime trends observed by IBM&#x27;s Emergency Response Services team in 2015: 1) an increase in &quot;onion-layered&quot; security incidents involving both unsophisticated and advanced attackers; 2) a rise in ransomware attacks that encrypt files and demand ransom; 3) growing threats from insider attacks; and 4) cybersecurity becoming a higher priority issue for management. It provides details on each trend and recommendations for organizations to improve security practices such as patching systems, increasing network visibility, training users, and having proper backup and response plans in place.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq65jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rq65jnf6"></div></div><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rn4q5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn4q5jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AbhinavMishra55">Abhinav Mishra</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1"> </div></div></div><div class="BottomRecommendationCard_root__gffTk SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/rlc-ppt/1621602"><span class="sr-only">EG2009 RLC on Social Media Ppt</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:16 / 9;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Quarterly Q4 2015 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rn8q5jnf6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rn8q5jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rn8q5jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ slideshow-author SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1"> </div></div></div></div><button aria-label="Previous" type="button" class="Slider_arrow__8LCca Slider_prev__YMssa Slider_hidden__rs7nK"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv"
