class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || The hitchhiker&#x27;s guide to north korea&#x27;s malware galaxy</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || The hitchhiker&#x27;s guide to north korea&#x27;s malware galaxy for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mnm6jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mnm6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mnm6jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mnm6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mnm6jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Christiaan F Beek, McAfee
Jay Rosenberg, Intezer Labs

The Lazarus, Silent Chollima, Group 123, Hidden Cobra, DarkSeoul, Blockbuster, Operation Troy, 10 Days of Rain attacks are all believed to originate from North Korea. But how can they be attributed with certainty? And what connection does a DDoS and disk wiping attack from July 4 2009, have with WannaCry, one of the largest cyber-attacks in the history of the cyber-sphere? 

We have conducted a comparative research over more than 10 years of malware and tools being used by North Korean adversaries. The results were intriguing and we will share our discoveries but also hunt tactics during our talk. We discovered new links between campaigns and were able to group malware families towards actor groups and discovere interesting patterns.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnm6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rnm6jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ro66jnf6:" popovertarget=":Ro66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ro66jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-retpoline-the-antispectre-type-2-mitigation-in-windows/119227043"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || Retpoline - the anti-spectre (type 2) mitigation in windows</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat v18 || Retpoline - the anti-spectre (type 2) mitigation in windows" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track2-am-retpoline-theanti-spectretype2mitigationinwindows-181012163929-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat v18 || Retpoline - the anti-spectre (type 2) mitigation in windows" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track2-am-retpoline-theanti-spectretype2mitigationinwindows-181012163929-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || Retpoline - the anti-spectre (type 2) mitigation in windows</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || Retpoline - the anti-spectre (type 2) mitigation in windows for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mo66jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mo66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mo66jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mo66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mo66jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Andrea Allievi, Microsoft

Spectre and Meltdown CPU have been one of the biggest security problem of the year 2018. Mitigations have already been delivered to the customers by both CPU manufacturers and OS developers. While the mitigations for Spectre type 1 and Meltdown have been successfully delivered, the mitigation for Spectre type 2, Retpoline, has been deferred for various problems. This talk will describe the implementation details of Retpoline in Windows 10 (19H1) and all the problem that we faced while testing it. Designing Retpoline has requested the collaboration of different teams in Microsoft, especially between the Kernel and the Compiler team. This talk will explain how we overcame all the implementation issues and allow all the involved Windows Kernel components to work with Retpoline in a retro-compatible way. At the end we will analyze the performance issues and explain how the Kernel team has found a solution for them</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro66jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rom6jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rom6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rom6jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-memory-resident-implants-code-injection-is-alive-and-well/119226832"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || Memory resident implants - code injection is alive and well</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat v18 || Memory resident implants - code injection is alive and well" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0926-track2-pm-memoryresidentimplants-codeinjectionisaliveandwell-181012163626-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat v18 || Memory resident implants - code injection is alive and well" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0926-track2-pm-memoryresidentimplants-codeinjectionisaliveandwell-181012163626-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || Memory resident implants - code injection is alive and well</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || Memory resident implants - code injection is alive and well for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mom6jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mom6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mom6jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mom6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mom6jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Luke Jennings, Countercept

Attackers have been avoiding disk and staying memory resident for over a decade and this has traditionally proven an Achilles heels for security products and the teams that operate them. The boom in both EDR products and memory forensics toolkits in more recent years have helped defenders to fight back but attackers are already adapting their approaches. 

This talk will cover both classic and modern techniques for injecting code into legitimate processes on Microsoft Windows systems, as well as several techniques for detecting them. This will include both system tracing methods, good for proactive detection, as well as memory analysis techniques that have the added benefit of allow detection of pre-existing compromises in real-world incident response scenarios, with a brief case study example. As part of this, practical examples will be given showing how Microsoft’s ATP and Sysmon help in this area as well as other techniques. Finally, the future of this area will be considered, including how the .NET runtime already complicates detection techniques in this area and how this will likely become increasingly challenging as more attackers discover and exploit this.

By the end of the talk, the audience should understand the importance of code injection in the context of memory-resident implants, the key techniques for performing it and detecting it and the challenges of achieving this in the real-world at enterprise scale.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rom6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rom6jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp66jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rp66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp66jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-massive-scale-usb-device-driver-fuzz-without-device/119226365"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || Massive scale usb device driver fuzz without device</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat v18 || Massive scale usb device driver fuzz without device" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track1-am-massivescaleusbdevicedriverfuzzwithoutdevice-181012162936-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat v18 || Massive scale usb device driver fuzz without device" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track1-am-massivescaleusbdevicedriverfuzzwithoutdevice-181012162936-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || Massive scale usb device driver fuzz without device</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || Massive scale usb device driver fuzz without device for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mp66jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mp66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mp66jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mp66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mp66jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Zhuo Ma, Tencent

USB is one of the most common interface supported on modern computer. Modern OSes offer tons of USB drivers to support frequently used USB device classes. For other 3rd party USB device, Microsoft provide automatic driver downloading and installation via Windows AutoUpdate Service. In this talk, we consider this as a novel attacking surface exposed by Windows.

We are trying to assess the vulnerability in those USB drivers provided via Windows AutoUpdate Service, which can be automatic installed and run after device plugged in. Obviously, these drivers are all designed for real USB device, which have to talk to device during running. 

So, the biggest obstacle for assessing these drivers is we can not prepare real USB devices for all of these drivers. To overcome this, We developed a system to emulate these USB device, further, we are trying to fuzz these drivers against our emulated USB device. By using this system, we can fuzz device drivers without the real USB device. In further, we can also precisely fuzz every stage of driver loading. We can feed any custom data to the drivers to trigger vulnerabilities. Also, this system supports IO Control Code fuzz as well. And all in all, all of this progress can be done automatically. 

We tested about 6000 drivers, yielded hundreds of crash by fuzzing. IO Control Fuzz also gave a reasonable result. We are going to divide our talk into three parts: the first part is about how we get the list of automatic installed USB drivers, and how to analyze these drivers in automatic ways; the second part is about the fuzzing system we designed, including the architecture of system, ways to emulating devices, key points for designing; the last part will show some vulnerabilities we found by this system.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp66jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpm6jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rpm6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpm6jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-modern-day-entomology-examining-the-inner-workings-of-the-bug-bazaar/119145473"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || Modern day entomology - examining the inner workings of the bu...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat v18 || Modern day entomology - examining the inner workings of the bu..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0926-track3-pm-moderndayentomology-examiningtheinnerworkingsofthebugbazaar-181011202716-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat v18 || Modern day entomology - examining the inner workings of the bu..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0926-track3-pm-moderndayentomology-examiningtheinnerworkingsofthebugbazaar-181011202716-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || Modern day entomology - examining the inner workings of the bu...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || Modern day entomology - examining the inner workings of the bu... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mpm6jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mpm6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mpm6jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mpm6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mpm6jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the modern zero-day exploit market and economy. It describes how vulnerabilities are found by researchers and sold through brokers to various parties, including governments, criminals, and exploit kit creators. It also outlines trends in the market, such as the impact of new mitigations, regulations, and events like Pwn2Own on the sale of exploits. Finally, it shares some examples of vulnerabilities the Zero Day Initiative has helped patch and the conclusion encourages questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rpm6jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rq66jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rq66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rq66jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-v18-the-matrix-has-you-protecting-linux-using-deception/119144744"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track2-pm-thematrixhasyou-protectinglinuxusingdeception-181011201719-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/0927-track2-pm-thematrixhasyou-protectinglinuxusingdeception-181011201719-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat v18 || The matrix has you - protecting linux using deception for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mq66jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mq66jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mq66jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mq66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mq66jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Ross Bevington, Microsoft

In ‘The Matrix’ sentient machines subdue the population by developing a highly sophisticated simulation. High interaction honeypots are a lot like The Matrix, designed to convince an attacker to execute an attack so we can monitor them. But these honeypots are flawed!

Attackers are continually adapting in order to evade our defenses - meaning that it’s often not enough to just set up a honeypot and watch the results roll in. Is a new approach better?

Did you know that 40% of IaaS VMs in Azure are Linux? For Microsoft to protect itself and its customers Linux is a priority.

At MSTIC we’ve developed a new type of Linux honeypot that allows us to deceive and control the behavior of an attacker. We are using this to understand the person behind the attack, examining them as they examine us. Using these techniques, we are able to better track the person behind the threat, build better protections and ultimately protect more Linux users - whether they are using Azure or not.

In this presentation I’ll show some of the successes of running a Matrix like environment, failures where a glitch was spotted as well as deception approaches that could be applied to other domains. Finally I’ll show how easy it is to leverage Azure’s big data capabilities to build and ultimately query all this data at scale as well as how you can immediately reap the benefits of this work by connecting your Linux box to Azure Security Center.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rq66jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rq66jnf6"></div></div><div class="desktop-recs"><div class="Slider_root__c0Jo8"><div class="Slider_scroller__KHjw4"><div class="BottomRecommendationCard_root__gffTk SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-seattle-2019-the-cake-is-a-lie-uncovering-the-secret-world-of-malwarelike-cheats-in-video-games/201112400"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:16 / 9;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/santiagopontirolifinal-191203232734-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/santiagopontirolifinal-191203232734-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save BlueHat Seattle 2019 || The cake is a lie! Uncovering the secret world of mal... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rm2q6jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rm2q6jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rm2q6jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rm2q6jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rm2q6jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MSbluehat">BlueHat Security Conference</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1"> </div></div></div><div class="BottomRecommendationCard_root__gffTk SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bluehat-seattle-2019-keynote/201077460"><span class="sr-only">BlueHat Seattle 2019 || Keynote</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:16 / 9;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img alt="BlueHat Seattle 2019 || Keynote" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/alexstamos-191203214951-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mgm7jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mgm7jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mgm7jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mgm7jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mgm7jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/VictorSzoltysek">VictorSzoltysek</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Only a few hundred people on the planet have done this — and even fewer have documented the journey like this.
In just one year, I passed all 12 AWS certifications and earned the ultra-rare AWS Gold Jacket — without burning out, without quitting my job, and without wasting hours on fluff.
My secret? A completely AI-powered study workflow using ChatGPT, custom prompts, and a technique I call DeepResearch — a strategy that pulls high-signal insights from Reddit, blogs, and real-world exam feedback to shortcut the noise and fast-track what actually matters.
This is the slide deck from my live talk — it breaks down everything:
✅ How I used ChatGPT to quiz, explain, and guide me
✅ How DeepResearch helped me prioritize the right content
✅ My top 80/20 study tips, service-specific rules of thumb, and real-world exam traps
✅ The surprising things that still trip up even experienced cloud teams
If you’re considering AWS certifications — or want to learn how to study smarter using AI — this is your blueprint.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgm7jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgm7jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rh67jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rh67jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rh67jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/a11y-webinar-series-level-up-your-accessibility-game_-a11y-audit-wcag-and-the-pokedex-of-a11y-pptx/278410592"><span class="sr-only">A11y Webinar Series - Level Up Your Accessibility Game_ A11y Audit, WCAG, and...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="A11y Webinar Series - Level Up Your Accessibility Game_ A11y Audit, WCAG, and..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/4-250425110842-146fb478-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="A11y Webinar Series - Level Up Your Accessibility Game_ A11y Audit, WCAG, and...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save A11y Webinar Series - Level Up Your Accessibility Game_ A11y Audit, WCAG, and... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mh67jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mh67jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mh67jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mh67jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mh67jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JuliaUndeutsch">Julia Undeutsch</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Are you ready to level up your accessibility knowledge? In this session, we’ll walk through my A11y audit template, learn how it’s helped me understand WCAG guidelines, and discover how you can use it to make impactful changes. I&#x27;ll take a quick detour into how A11y can help you become active in open source, and how open source can help you improve your a11y skills.

Laura Wissiak will also join the session, and together we’ll dive deep into the POUR principles (Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, Robust) and discuss how to turn audit results into meaningful, actionable tickets that improve accessibility.

With her Pokédex of accessibility you will understand why aiming for AAA accessibility standards isn’t just a goal—it’s about striving for the best, just like in video games. Why play to just pass when you can master the game? Let’s elevate our accessibility efforts together!

Focus: A11y Audit, WCAG 2.1, POUR, Ticketing, Open Source

Target audience: Everyone (Project Managers, Designers, Developers, Testers, and Pokémon Lovers)</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rh67jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rh67jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhm7jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rhm7jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhm7jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/monitor-kafka-clients-centrally-with-kip-714/278201852"><span class="sr-only">Monitor Kafka Clients Centrally with KIP-714</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Monitor Kafka Clients Centrally with KIP-714" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/kip-714clientmonitoring-250421050720-0ac8f3d9-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Monitor Kafka Clients Centrally with KIP-714" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/kip-714clientmonitoring-250421050720-0ac8f3d9-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Monitor Kafka Clients Centrally with KIP-714</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Monitor Kafka Clients Centrally with KIP-714 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mhm7jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mhm7jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mhm7jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mhm7jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mhm7jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/keshav2910">Kumar Keshav</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Apache Kafka introduced KIP-714 in 3.7 release, which allows the Kafka brokers to centrally track client metrics on behalf of applications. The broker can subsequently relay these metrics to a remote monitoring system, facilitating the effective monitoring of Kafka client health and the identification of any problems.

KIP-714 is useful to Kafka operators because it introduces a way for Kafka brokers to collect and expose client-side metrics via a plugin-based system. This significantly enhances observability by allowing operators to monitor client behavior (including producers, consumers, and admin clients) directly from the broker side.
Before KIP-714, client metrics were only available within the client applications themselves, making centralized monitoring difficult. With this improvement, operators can now access client performance data, detect anomalies, and troubleshoot issues more effectively. It also simplifies integrating Kafka with external monitoring systems like Prometheus or Grafana.

This talk covers setting up ClientOtlpMetricsReporter that aggregates OpenTelemetry Protocol (OTLP) metrics received from the client, enhances them with additional client labels and forwards them via gRPC client to an external OTLP receiver. The plugin is implemented in Java and requires the JAR to be added to the Kafka broker libs.

Be it a kafka operator or a client application developer, this talk is designed to enhance your knowledge of efficiently tracking the health of client applications.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhm7jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhm7jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ri67jnf6:" popovertarget=":Ri67jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ri67jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/introduction-to-llm-post-training-mit-6-s191-2025/278217942"><span class="sr-only">Introduction to LLM Post-Training - MIT 6.S191 2025</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Introduction to LLM Post-Training - MIT 6.S191 2025" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontodl-mit-250421134121-a4aea1ab-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Introduction to LLM Post-Training - MIT 6.S191 2025" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontodl-mit-250421134121-a4aea1ab-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Introduction to LLM Post-Training - MIT 6.S191 2025</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Introduction to LLM Post-Training - MIT 6.S191 2025 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R5mi67jnf6:" popovertarget=":R5mi67jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R5mi67jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5mi67jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5mi67jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/labonnemaxime">Maxime Labonne</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In this talk, we will cover the fundamentals of modern LLM post-training at various scales with concrete examples. High-quality data generation is at the core of this process, focusing on the accuracy, diversity, and complexity of the training samples. We will explore key training techniques, including supervised fine-tuning, preference alignment, and model merging. The lecture will delve into evaluation frameworks with their pros and cons for measuring model performance. We will conclude with an overview of emerging trends in post-training methodologies and their implications for the future of LLM development.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri67jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ri67jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rim7jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rim7jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rim7jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/buckeye-dreamin-2023-de-fogging-debug-logs/278465196"><span class="sr-only">Buckeye Dreamin&#x27; 2023: De-fogging Debug Logs</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Buckeye Dreamin&#x27; 2023: De-fogging Debug Logs" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/debuglogs-250426233535-20c30b6b-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Are you spending too much time pulling data, fixing AP delays, and manually processing reports in QuickBooks? 

You’re not alone. Many finance teams hit a point where QuickBooks holds them back more than it helps.

The good news – there’s a better way. 

Those who moved off QuickBooks instantly noticed how fast they can close the books, automate their cumbersome practices, and be able to create custom reports.  

Join us for a 30-minute virtual Lunch &amp; Learn where we’ll break down what it really means to outgrow QuickBooks, and how to take the next step with confidence.  

During this session, you’ll learn: 

The top signs it’s time to graduate from QuickBooks 
Common challenges finance teams face and how modern ERPs solve them 
Tips to evaluate and select a more comprehensive ERP system 
QuickBooks vs. Cloud ERPs: A side-by-side look  
Live Q&amp;A to get all your questions answered

✅ Topics covered:

Static and dynamic test techniques

Black-box testing (Equivalence Partitioning, Boundary Value Analysis, Decision Tables, State Transition Testing, etc.)

White-box testing (Statement and Decision coverage)

Experience-based techniques (Exploratory Testing, Error Guessing, Checklists)

Choosing appropriate test design techniques based on context

SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">You know you need to invest in a CRM platform, you just need to invest in the right one for your business.
It sounds easy enough but, with the onslaught of information out there, the decision-making process can be quite convoluted.

In a recent webinar we compared two options – HubSpot’s Sales Hub and Salesforce’s Sales Cloud – and explored ways to help you determine which CRM is better for your business.</span></div></div><div RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Welcome to this tutorial where we break down the complex topic of radio spectrum in a clear and accessible way.
In this video, we explore: 
✅ What is spectrum, frequency, and bandwidth?
✅ How does wavelength affect antenna design?
✅ The difference between FDD and TDD
✅ 5G spectrum ranges – FR1 and FR2
✅ The role of mmWave, and why it&#x27;s misunderstood
✅ What makes 5G Non-Standalone (NSA) different from 5G Standalone (SA)
✅ Concepts like Carrier Aggregation, Dual Connectivity, and Dynamic Spectrum Sharing (DSS)
✅ Why spectrum refarming is critical for modern mobile networks
✅ Evolution of antennas from legacy networks to Massive MIMO
Whether you&#x27;re just getting started with wireless technology or brushing up on the latest in 5G and beyond, this video is designed to help you learn and stay up to date.

href="https://www.slideshare.net/carlyakerly1">carlyakerly1</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This session takes you back to the core principles for for successfully utilizing and operating Delta Lake. We break down the fundamentals—Delta Lake’s structure, transaction management, and data retention strategies—while showcasing its powerful features like time travel for seamless rollback and vacuuming for efficient cleanup.

Demonstrations will teach you how to create and manage tables, execute transactions, and optimize performance with proven techniques. Walk away with a clear understanding of how to harness Delta Lake’s full potential for scalable, reliable data management.

Speakers: Scott Haines (Nike) &amp; Youssef Mirini (Databricks)

By: Kaya Weers
Given at various conferences and Meetups </span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rom7jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rom7jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="latest-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rp67jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rp67jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rp67jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/autopilot-for-everyone-series-session-3-exploring-real-world-use-cases/278272646"><span class="sr-only">Autopilot for Everyone Series - Session 3: Exploring Real-World Use Cases!
Join us for an interactive session where we explore real-world use cases of UiPath Autopilot, the AI-powered automation assistant.

📕 In this engaging event, we will:
- demonstrate how UiPath Autopilot enhances productivity by combining generative AI, machine learning, and automation to streamline business processes
- discover how UiPath Autopilot enables intelligent task automation with natural language inputs and AI-powered decision-making for smarter workflows
Whether you&#x27;re new to automation or a seasoned professional, don&#x27;t miss out on this opportunity to transform your approach to business automation.
Register now and step into the future of efficient work processes!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp67jnf6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="--fallback-aspect-ratio:undefined / undefined" data-testid="freestar-ad-container"><div><div class="" id="between-recs-ad-2"></div></div></div></div></div><!--/$--><div class="Transcript_root__Vrf6Q"><h2 class="Transcript_title__YgAka"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/file.5db1ba24.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span>BlueHat v17 || 10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing | Billy Leonard </h2><div><ul class="Transcript_list__faItj"><div><li>1. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#1">Threat Analysis Group
November </a> 2017 - @billyleonard
10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing
 </li></div><div><li>2. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#2">Threat Analysis Group
Billy </a> Leonard
Threat Analysis Group
 </li></div><div><li>3. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#3">Threat Analysis Group
But </a> first, ….
 </li></div><div><li>4. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#4">Threat Analysis Group
What </a> we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.
 </li></div><div><li>5. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#5">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>6. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#6">Threat Analysis Group
Targeted </a> attacks are all really advanced.
 </li></div><div><li>7. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#7">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>8. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#8">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>9. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#9">Threat Analysis Group
The </a> Early Days.
 </li></div><div><li>10. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#10">Threat Analysis Group
 </a> </li></div><div><li>11. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#11">Threat Analysis Group

 </li></div><div><li>13. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#13">Threat Analysis Group

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []

type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"name":"slideshow","edgeTestAssignments":[{"name":"example","variant":"B"},{"name":"nextjs_profile","variant":"B"},{"name":"nextjs_profile_v2","variant":"B"},{"name":"recs_model","variant":"C"},{"name":"sections","variant":"A"}],"layout":{"currentUser":null,"fullPath":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578","osanoId":"079b27eb-bb3f-48dd-9bd9-3feb8aec3c38","featureFlags":[{"name":"disable_facebook","enabled":true},{"name":"document_interstitials_flag","enabled":true},{"name":"recommendation_impression_tracking","enabled":true},{"name":"search_results_tracking","enabled":true},{"name":"view_restriction_without_subscription_after_five","enabled":true},{"name":"disable_lazy_hydration","enabled":false}]},"countryCodeFromFastly":"US","slideshow":{"username":"MSbluehat","allowDownloads":true,"allowDownloadOriginalFile":true,"allowEmbeds":true,"canonicalUrl":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578","categories":[{"id":"16","name":"Technology","url":"technology"}],"createdAt":"2017-12-09 00:22:50 UTC","description":"While it's not kernel 0days or EMET bypasses, credential phishing has been a go-to in attackers toolboxes for many years, rising to prominence during the run up to the 2016 US Presidential Elections. Being able to access a target's email or files stored in the cloud without burning your prized 0day has proven to be too much for even the most advanced attackers to pass up. In this talk, we will look at how attackers have evolved and adapted their credential phishing operations over the past 10 years, from changes in delivery mechanisms to changes in persistence and exfiltration and how defenses have evolved during that same time. It defines a targeted attack as one where threat actors actively pursue and compromise a specific target's infrastructure while maintaining anonymity. Targeted attacks are considered such when attackers have a specific target in mind. The main goal is to infiltrate the target's network and steal information. These attacks are persistent, with attackers expending significant effort to ensure the attack continues beyond the initial infiltration. Motives include information theft, espionage, and sabotage. Various tools are used in targeted attacks, and targets can be individuals, organizations, or sectors like finance, telecom, or healthcare. Case studies of past targeted attacks are also presented.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/targeted-attacks-62950126/62950126","userLogin":"expert4u","userName":"Rahul","viewCount":833},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"Inside Attacker: An Overview","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":20,"score":0.3456,"slideshowId":"80218218","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"inside-attacker-an-overview","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/insideattacker-anoverview-170927140635-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"An insider attacker is defined as a current or former employee, contractor, or other trusted entity that has access to an organization's network, systems, or data and intentionally or unintentionally misuses that access. Insider attacks account for 30-50% of cybersecurity incidents according to various studies. Insider threats can be malicious, negligent, or accidental. They are challenging to detect and prevent because insiders have legitimate access that makes their harmful actions difficult to distinguish from regular job functions. Potential solutions include improving security visibility, using red and blue teams to test defenses, following security standards for development, and monitoring behaviors for anomalies using artificial intelligence. However, overly complex security can also reduce productivity.","tags":["devops","information security"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/inside-attacker-an-overview/80218218","userLogin":"DustinCollins1","userName":"Dustin Collins","viewCount":338},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"[DSC DACH 24] AI 4 Bad: A Look into Its Misuse and Why Knowing It Matters for...","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":24,"score":0.3389,"slideshowId":"271883856","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"dsc-dach-24-ai-4-bad-a-look-into-its-misuse-and-why-knowing-it-matters-for-ai-4-good-tereza-votypkova","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/terezavotypkovaai4bad-240918231713-4df4ea65-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"As artificial intelligence continues to advance, its potential to address all kinds of complex problems grows. Over 5+ years, ShadyRAT compromised over 70 victims, maintaining persistence for an average of 9 months to steal data. Attackers used open-source intelligence to profile targets, then sent malicious emails to install remote access tools allowing command and control. Whether it was the evolution of DDoS attacks into the record-shattering Mirai botnet that disrupted large portions of the internet or insidious commercial banking Trojans available for sale as ready-made malware kits, the tone of cyberattacks darkened in 2016 while illuminating one key fact: many companies are not applying basic security fundamentals to their IT environments.\r\n\r\nAttend this webinar to learn:\r\n\r\nThe top-level security trends from 2016, and what it could mean for 2017, including the political and intellectual property concerns stemming from large-scale data leaks\r\nWhy classic attack vectors continue to be a weapon of choice for those seeking to disrupt operations and steal data\r\nWhy a lower attack rate for the average security client may not be good news\r\nWhat steps your organization can take to protect against these attacks","tags":["security","ibmsecurity","webinar"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/supersized-security-threats-can-you-stop-2016-from-repeating/74985512","userLogin":"ValerieLanzone","userName":"Valerie Lanzone","viewCount":259},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"An Underground education","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":73,"score":0.3114,"slideshowId":"21151795","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"underground-education-21151795","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/undergroundeducation-130514025502-phpapp01-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"The document discusses counterintelligence processes and threats, as well as how professional thieves and hackers have approached counterintelligence. It notes that professional thieves in the late 19th-early 20th century had loose organizational structures, no controlled territory, and no ability to adapt when law enforcement changed tactics, leading to their decline. Hackers today operate with flat structures and in controlled territories like Russia and China, but English hacker communities in hostile environments have developed stronger counterintelligence through necessity. Overall, the document argues that groups must engage in adaptive denial, learning from failures and adapting security practices, or they will not survive competitive threats.","tags":["grugq","opsec","comsec"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/underground-education-21151795/21151795","userLogin":"grugq","userName":"grugq","viewCount":15892},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"10 Critical Corporate Cyber Security Risks","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":29,"score":0.3112,"slideshowId":"49737025","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"10-critical-corporate-cyber-security-risks","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/10criticalcorporatecybersecurityrisks-150623140209-lva1-app6891-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Do you know what brings cyber security risks to your organization? Introduction\nAs technology continues to advance, so do the threats that accompany it. Hackers, who once were a rare breed of computer experts, have become more and more common. Among these hackers, there is a category known as script kiddies. While they lack the skills of more experienced hackers, they can still cause significant damage to businesses and individuals.\n\n2. What are script kiddies?\nScript kiddies are individuals who use existing tools and techniques to launch attacks against computer systems and networks without fully understanding how they work. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploits. Instead, they rely on pre-packaged tools and scripts to carry out attacks.\n\n3. How do script kiddies operate?\nScript kiddies typically use automated tools to scan for vulnerable systems and networks. Once they identify a potential target, they use pre-written scripts and tools to exploit any vulnerabilities they find. These attacks can take many forms,Famous script kiddie groups\nThe evolution of script kiddies\nConclusion\nFAQs\n1. They are often young, inexperienced, and lack the technical knowledge required to create their own tools and exploit","tags":["table of contents","1. introduction","2. what are script kiddies?"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-are-script-kiddiespdf/259356000","userLogin":"itmaster9","userName":"uzair ","viewCount":53},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"Scanned by CamScannerWRTG 391  Writing Assignment .docx","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":17,"score":0.3097,"slideshowId":"254052627","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"scanned-by-camscannerwrtg-391-writing-assignment-docx","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/scannedbycamscannerwrtg391writingassignment-221107174127-661ef786-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Scanned by CamScanner\n\n\n\n\nWRTG 391  \nWriting Assignment #3 \n\nSynthesis Essay  \n(sometimes called a Literature Review) \n\nWriting Assignment #3 will be a synthesis essay, a format that is sometimes referred to as \na literature review.  \nOrganization:  \n \nYour synthesis essay should be organized in the following manner: \n\n• Introduction: Write one or two paragraphs in which you introduce the reader to your \ntopic.  \n\n• Body -- the categories into which you are dividing the literature: Divide your sources \ninto a few categories.  A suggestion is that you divide them into three to five \ncategories. \n\n• Conclusion: Summarize what the literature says on your topic. \n\nApproach: \n\nThis semester, you have critiqued an author’s analysis in the critique essay and have critically \nevaluated several articles in the annotated bibliography.  In this assignment you will synthesize the \nideas of several authors in a synthesis essay, or literature review. \n\nFor your annotated bibliography, you selected a topic based on your interests and, possibly, your \nmajor.  You constructed a list of 12 references and summarized and critically analyzed them in 150-\n200 words each. \n\nThrough this process, you may have seen patterns in the scholarly literature in the topic on which you \nconducted research.  For example, consider the following examples: \n\n• You may have researched studies in criminal justice and found that there are varying \nopinions on how to respond to criminal behavior among youth.  \n\n• You may have researched studies in psychology and found that counseling strategies for \nvictims of domestic abuse tend to fall into four categories. \n\n• You may have researched graphic communications and discovered that the integration of \ngraphics in business report writing has evolved from the 1970s to the present because of \nadvancements in technology.  \n\n• You may have researched articles on gerontology and found studies that answered three \nbasic questions on how older adults respond to training for physical performance. \n\n In the synthesis essay, you will focus your research efforts in a particular area, perhaps \nas a response to what you found while writing the annotated bibliography.  You will then \nconduct more research and synthesize your findings in this synthesis essay. \n\n\n\nPlease note that the annotated bibliography was the beginning, not the end, of your research.  You \nmight decide to disregard several of the articles you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography \nbecause they don’t speak to the specific area on which you have decided to write your synthesis \nessay.  You might select one article that you analyzed in the critical annotated bibliography, look up \nthe articles cited in that article, and “snowball” your research in that way.  \n\nIn other words, this process is a recursive one.  You might find reasons to hone in on and narrow your \ntopic even further after you have written the annotated bibliography. \n\n How to organize the synthesis essay: \n\nW.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/scanned-by-camscannerwrtg-391-writing-assignment-docx/254052627","userLogin":"anhlodge","userName":"anhlodge","viewCount":16},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"Peerlyst Delhi NCR Chapter Meet","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":16,"score":0.3094,"slideshowId":"71588526","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"peerlyst-delhi-ncr-chapter-meet","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/peerlystdelhincrchaptermeetv1-170131134435-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"This document summarizes a Peerlyst meetup in Delhi-NCR, India organized by chapter leads Abhinav Mishra and Ankit Giri. This is one of the many reasons behind the existence and rapid growth of a multi-million dollar industry that thrives on selling cheats, hacks and modifications to desperate gamers seeking to gain the upper hand in their next match. Let's dissect these tools and understand how modern games and anti-cheating technologies can be easily bypassed, all while we get a glimpse of the dubious market and supporting crews that develop, sell, and maintain the commodities in this illegal economy. It's not unusual for cheats to be more expensive than the actual games they are trying to profit from, or for players to buy a single title over and over until they can avoid being banned by the protective measures implemented in the first place. Fortnite? Overwatch? League of Legends? If you've heard about these games but you don't know what an aim-bot, a wall-hack, or an ESP means, then you might finally understand why all those competitive matches you played have made you feel like a fish out of water. Join me in this presentation and learn the inside-out of an industry that has remained in the shadows for a very long time.
